article.title: The strong coupling: a theoretical perspective

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the top-left plot of Figure 1 primarily illustrate?
choices: The impact of different jet algorithms on the extracted αs value.
The need for hadronisation corrections in matching theoretical predictions to data at hadron level.
The dependence of the extracted αs value on the choice of the ycut parameter.
The difference in strong coupling values obtained from ALEPH and OPAL data.

multiple_choice_question.text: Table 1 presents various αs determinations from e+e− collisions. Which of the following observations is supported by the data in the table?
choices: Determinations using the thrust variable consistently yield lower αs values compared to those using jet rates.
There is a significant discrepancy between the central values of αs obtained from different methods, even though they describe the same physical phenomenon.
All determinations using NNLO+NLL+MChad achieve uncertainties below 0.0030.
The ALEPH 3-jet rate determination shows significantly larger uncertainties than all other listed determinations.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation 2 presents the αs determination from the thrust (SCET) with the highest quoted precision. What is the dominant source of uncertainty in this result?
choices: Experimental uncertainties (exp.)
Hadronisation uncertainties (hadr.)
Perturbative uncertainties (pert.)
Uncertainties from the choice of renormalisation scale (µ).

multiple_choice_question.text: Table 2 shows αs extractions from τ decays using different theoretical approaches. What key difference in theoretical treatment is represented by the "FOPT" and "CIPT" choices?
choices: FOPT uses fixed-order perturbation theory while CIPT incorporates contour-improved perturbation theory, accounting for the running of αs.
FOPT incorporates fixed-order estimates of non-perturbative contributions, while CIPT determines them from a fit to data.
FOPT relies solely on data from the ALEPH experiment, while CIPT combines data from both ALEPH and OPAL.
FOPT and CIPT represent different choices for the renormalisation scale (µ) used in the perturbative calculation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key aspect of the ALPHA collaboration\'s approach to determining αs does Figure 2 primarily illustrate?
choices: The use of step-scaling to relate αs values obtained at different lattice scales.
The impact of different choices for the renormalisation scale (µ) on the extracted αs value.
The dependence of the extracted αs value on the specific choice of lattice fermion action.
The comparison of αs extractions using different short-distance quantities, such as Wilson loops and heavy-quark correlators.
